1.text: This is a sure word: if a man aspires to the office of overseer, he desires a good work.

2.text: The overseer must be irreproachable, a husband of one wife, self-controlled, sensible, modest, hospitable and a good teacher.

3.text: He must not be a drinker, or someone violent or greedy for money. He should be gentle, not irritable or envious.

4.text: He should be someone who rules his own house well, keeping his [own] children in subjection with all reverence.

5.text: (Indeed, if a man does not know how to rule his own house, how can he take care of the Church of God?)

6.text: He should not be a new convert, for fear that being puffed up with pride he may fall into the same condemnation as the devil.

7.text: Moreover, he must have good testimony from those who are outside in order to avoid falling into [public] blame and the snare of the devil.

8.text: Deacons, in the same way, must be reverent, not double-tongued, not addicted to much wine and not greedy for money.

9.text: They should keep the mystery of the faith with a pure conscience.

10.text: Let them also be tested first; then let them serve if they are blameless.

11.text: Likewise, their wives must be reverent, not slanderers but self-controlled and faithful in all things.

12.text: Deacons should be husbands of one wife, ruling their children and their own houses well.

13.text: Those who have served well earn for themselves a good standing and great boldness in the faith which is in Christ Jesus.

14.text: I write to you these things, hoping to come to you shortly.

15.text: If I am delayed, I want you to know how the people should behave in the house of God, which is the Church of the living God, the pillar and foundation of the truth.

16.text: Without a doubt, great is the mystery of godliness:  God was revealed in the flesh,   vindicated in [the] spirit,   seen by angels,   preached among the nations,   believed on in the world,   and received up in glory.
